Republic of Indonesia

The Project will form part of the rural infrastructure component of 
the Government’s ongoing Fuel Subsidy Reduction Compensation 
Program  (PKPS-BBM),  and  it  will  rehabilitate  and  improve  rural 
infrastructure  in  about  1,800  poor  and/or  isolated  villages  in  less 
developed districts in East Java, Nusa Tenggara East, South East 
Sulawesi, and South Sulawesi provinces. The Project will follow a 
community-driven development approach and will benefit about 2 
million people or about 400,000 households. 
 
The Government’s National Poverty Reduction Strategy identifies 
lack  of  basic  infrastructure  in  the  rural  areas  as  an  underlying 
cause of poverty, and the Medium Term Development Plan 2004–
2009 (MTDP) identifies investing into rural infrastructure as a key 
action  for  reducing  poverty.  The  MTDP  identifies  investment 
needs of about $145 billion in infrastructure necessary to maintain 
a  sustained  GDP  growth  rate  of  6%  and  for  making  steady 
progress  towards  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDG) 
during  the  planned  period.  Of  these,  public  sector  requirements 
are  estimated  at  about  $25  billion  for  infrastructure,  such  as  that 
for  rural  areas,  that  is  traditionally  unattractive  for  the  private 
sector.  However,  investments  in  infrastructure  have  seen  drastic 
decline from about $16 billion in 1996 to $3 billion in 2001 and to 
$1.5 billion in 2002. 
 
The urgency of investments in rural infrastructure has further risen 
with  the  Government’s  ambitious  plan  to  reduce  fuel  subsidies. 
The  direct  impact  on  the  poor  and  near  poor  of,  for  example,  a 
recent 186% rise in the price of kerosene is potentially substantial. 
Impacts resulting from higher transportation and energy costs will 
raise  the  general  inflation  levels.  The  direct  and  indirect  impacts 
could further aggravate poverty levels and may lead to slippages 
in  progress  towards  attaining  MDGs.  To  mitigate  these  impacts 
and  aid  the  poor  and  near  poor,  the  Government  has  adopted  a 
number of measures, including the rural infrastructure component

communities. On account of resource constraints, the coverage of 
the PKPS-BBM in 2005 is limited to about 12,800 (about 20%) of 
the  villages  in  Indonesia,  which  leaves  a  large  unserved  rural 
population.  In  2006,  the  PKPS-BBM  targets  an  additional  9,000 
villages.  The  Project  will  support  expansion  of  the  Government 
program  in  an  additional  1,800  villages  with  high  incidences  of 
poverty  and  poor  rural  infrastructure.  That  will  raise  the  overall 
Program coverage to 23,600 villages. 
 
The Project’s long-term objective is to improve welfare of the rural 
communities, and the immediate objective is to improve access of 
the poor and near poor in rural areas to basic rural infrastructure. 
 
The  Project  will  be  implemented  as  a  part  of  the  PKPS-BBM,

equivalent, of which $10.66 million (18%) is the foreign exchange 
cost  and  $50.16  million  equivalent  (82%)  is  the  local  currency 
cost.

Loan Amount and Terms  A  loan  of  SDR35.08  million  from  the  Asian  Development  Fund 
resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will be provided. 
The  loan  will  have  a  32-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  8 
years,  with  an  interest  charge  of  1%  per  year  during  the  grace 
period and 1.5% per year during the remaining period. 
 
The Government will provide the loan proceeds to communities on 
an  on-grant  basis.  The  grants  to  the  individual  villages  will  be 
disbursed  in  three  tranches,  with  the  first  tranche  released  upon 
approval  of  the  community’s  infrastructure  rehabilitation  and 
improvement  plans.  The  remaining  amounts  will  be  disbursed 
based upon project progress.

The  Project  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of  30  months  as 
part  of  the  Rural  Infrastructure  Component  in  the  Government’s 
ongoing  PKPS-BBM.  It  will  use  the  existing  implementation 
mechanisms  that  are  in  place  for  that  program.  The  project 
coordination  and  monitoring  unit  at  the  national  level  will  be 
responsible for  the  management,  coordination,  and  monitoring  of 
project activities. The existing provincial- and district-level project 
implementation  units  will  be  responsible  for  providing  social  and 
technical  facilitation  to  the  communities  in  undertaking  the 
improvement  activities.  The 
infrastructure  rehabilitation  and 
National  Coordination  Team  and 
the  National  Steering 
Committee, established for the PKPS-BBM, will be responsible for 
providing guidance and oversight to the Project. 
 
The  Ministry  of  Public  Works  through  its  Directorate  General  of 
Human Settlements will be the Executing Agency for the Project. 
 
All  goods  and  related  services  financed  under  the  ADB  loan  will

An  estimated  702  person-months  of  consulting  services, 
comprising  8  person-months  of  international  and  694  person-
months  of  domestic  consultants,  will  be  recruited  to  assist  the 
Government in implementing the Project. Eight person-months of 
international, and 16 person-months of domestic consulting, along 
with  an  appropriate  number  of  technical  support  staff,  will  be 
recruited on individual bases, while the remaining services will be 
procured  through  a  domestic  consulting  firm.  Consultants  will  be 
recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants,  using  the  quality  and  cost-based  system  and  other 
arrangements  satisfactory

The  Project  will  benefit  about  2  million  rural  poor  in  about  1,800 
poor  and/or  isolated  villages.  The  likely  types  of  infrastructure 
include  village  roads,  bridges  and  culverts,  village  irrigation 
schemes,  water  supply  and  sanitation  schemes,  and  drainage 
works.  Main  benefits  are  anticipated  to  include  (i)  reduced 
transportation  costs,  (ii)  improved  access  to  safe  drinking  water, 
(iii)  improved  access  to  sanitation  facilities,  (iv)  improved  crop 
production,  and 
long-term  employment 
generation.  The  experience  from  recent  projects  indicates  that 
such investments are economically viable, with economic internal 
rates of returns from the rural roads, irrigation schemes, and water 
supply schemes ranging from 28% to 85%.

Risks and Assumptions 

The  main  risks  the  Project  is  likely  to  face  include  (i) possibly 
inadequate  preparatory  activities  on  the  part  of  the  Government, 
(ii)  possibly  inadequate  implementation  capacities  at  local  levels, 
(iii)  benefits  accruing  to  a  few  nonpoor,  (iv)  poor  governance,  (v) 
sustainability of the policies and investments, (vi) start-up delays, 
(vii)  delays  in  budget  approval,  and  (viii)  lack  of  adequate 
counterpart funds. The Project design provides for measures that 
should be able to mitigate or minimize the perceived risks.

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

2. 
The rural areas in Indonesia are home to the largest segment of the population and of 
the poor. Based on official estimates,1 the number of rural poor in 2004 was about 24.7 million, 
or  one  fifth  of  the  rural  population.  That  represents  a  reduction  of  about  7.6  million  (about  7 
percentage points) from the levels immediately following the 1997–98 Asian financial crisis. The 
poverty levels underestimate poverty, however, by not taking into account seasonal or transient 
poverty. An assessment of rural poverty,2 using the difference in incidence between $1/day and 
$2/day  headcounts  as  a  proxy  for  vulnerability,  reports  that  as  much  as  45%  of  the  overall 
Indonesian  population  may  be  vulnerable  to  periodic  shocks.  Although  separate  estimates  on 
the size of the vulnerable population in rural areas are not available, the extent of vulnerability is 
expected to be at least similar if not higher for the rural population. The vulnerable in Indonesia 
live with risk as a part of their lives, and shocks at the national or regional levels can sink them 
into poverty at any time.  
  
The  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy  paper  (PRSP) 3  and  Medium  Term 
3. 
Development  Plan  for  2004–2009 4 (MTDP)  identify  lack  of  key  infrastructure  as  one  of  the 
underlying causes of poverty. Poor or difficult access to villages mean that the communities do 
not receive fair prices for their produce and they pay higher prices for their consumption. Poor 
access  also  means  a  tendency  for  poor  coverage  of  public  and  private  services  and  higher 
costs of accessing outside services. According to the MTDP, about 54% of the rural villages are 
not connected through asphalt roads, and about one third of these lack year-round access even 
by  four  wheel  drive  vehicles.  A  quick  assessment  undertaken  by  the  country  poverty  analysis 
showed  that  in  isolated  areas  dependent  on  non-motor  vehicle  modes  of  transportation, 
communities identified high transportation costs as a major cause of poverty. According to the 
National  Socio-Economic  Survey, 5  more  than  40%  of  Indonesian  households  did  not  have 
access  to  clean  drinking  water  or  sanitation  facilities  in  2003.  Among  rural  households,  only 
15%  were  obtaining  drinking  water  from  piped  or  pumped  sources,  and  just  21%  had  septic 
tanks  for  final  disposal  of  human  waste.  The  impacts  of  low  levels  of  access  to  safe  drinking 
water and lack of adequate sanitation facilities contribute to high incidence of such water-borne 
diseases  as  diarrhea,  intestinal  worms,  and  skin  diseases.  The  incidence  is  higher  among 
children and the elderly, and diarrhea is the second-largest cause of death and stunted growth 
among young children. The infant mortality rate of 35 per 1,000 live births in 2000 is the highest 
among Southeast Asian countries.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Adequacy and Sustainability of Rural Infrastructure 

Historically,  Indonesia  has  had  high  levels  of  public  and  private  investments  into 
4. 
infrastructure.  However,  the  investment  levels  have  dropped  sharply  since  the  1997–98  Asian 
financial  crisis.  In  current  terms,  such  public  expenditures  declined  from  about  $16  billion  in 
1996  to  $3  billion  in  2001  and  to  $1.5  billion  in  2002.  Declining  investments  mean  that 
infrastructure  expansion  has  slowed  and  existing  infrastructure  has  deteriorated.  A  recent 
assessment6 has  ranked  Indonesia  at  the  bottom  in  terms  of  infrastructure  amongst  countries 
with  populations  of  more  than  20  million.  According  to  the  village  potentials  survey, 7  the 
proportion of rural villages with year-round access by four wheel drive vehicles improved only by 
about  2  percentage  points  between  1993  and  2003  from  80%  to  82%.  Over  the  same  period, 
the proportion of villages accessible by asphalt roads declined by about 2 percentage points to 
45%  in  2003.  Between  1993  and  2003,  improvements  in  access  to  safe  drinking  water  and 
sanitation  in  rural  areas  were  relatively  larger,  at  6%  and  22%,  respectively.  However,  the 
overall coverage remains low. 
 
5. 
Low levels of investment have also had adverse affects on the sustainability of existing 
infrastructure  and  service  delivery  levels.  According  to  the  MTDP,  the  condition  of  46%  of  the 
overall road network and 57% of the district roads is categorized as lightly to heavily damaged. 
Similarly,  the  irrigation  schemes,  representing  an  important  infrastructure  element  in  the 
predominantly agriculture-based economy, are in a poor state. Up to 30% of the schemes are 
categorized  as  degraded.  Appendix  1  presents  a  more  detailed  analysis  of  the  sector-related 
issues and experiences. 
 

2. 

Opportunities 

The PRSP and Agriculture and Rural Development Strategy8 identify investing into rural 
6. 
infrastructure as a key area in reducing poverty and regional disparities, as well as for achieving 
the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs),  as  these  investments  improve  poor  people’s 
access  to  services  and  markets  while  generating  employment.  A  recent  Asian  Development 
Bank  (ADB)  study9 confirmed  that,  in  addition  to  the  income-related  impacts,  investments  into 
infrastructure  also  generate  such  non-income  impacts  as  improvements  in  health,  education, 
security, and participation. Taking into account the potential role of infrastructure development in 
reducing poverty, the MTDP emphasizes the need for increased investments into infrastructure 
in general and into rural infrastructure in particular. According to Government estimates, in order 
for  Indonesia  to  maintain  an  annual  GDP  growth  rate  of  6%  over  the  period  2005–2009, 
infrastructure investments of $145 billion are needed. Of that amount, $25 billion in public sector 
investments have been identified specifically in such areas as rural roads, irrigation, and other 
rural infrastructure that are typically not attractive for the private sector.

12.

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

17. 
The Government has requested ADB to assist in improving rural infrastructure as a part 
of its ongoing initiatives under the PKPS-BBM to mitigate the adverse impacts on the poor and 
near poor of reduced fuel subsidies. The Project’s long-term objective is to improve the welfare 
of  rural  communities,  and  the  immediate  objective  is  to  improve  access  to  basic  rural 
infrastructure  for  the  poor  and  near  poor  in  rural  areas.  The  Project’s  design  and  monitoring 
framework is Appendix 4.  
 
18. 
The Project will implement a geographic slice of the 2006–2007 PKPS-BBM where it will 
cover selected provinces in eastern Indonesia with poverty levels higher and achievement levels 
on the Millennium Development Goals lower than national averages. The selection of provinces 
also  took  into  account  the  number  of  less  developed  districts  and  presence  of  infrastructure-
poor villages. The selected provinces are East Java, Nusa Tenggara East, South East Sulawesi, 
and  South  Sulawesi.  The  poverty  profiles  of  the  selected  provinces  are  presented  in 
Supplementary  Appendix  A.  Within  these  provinces,  the  Project  will  focus  on  less  developed 
districts15 with high poverty levels, sufficient implementation capacities, and adequate numbers 
of  villages  that  are  eligible  for support.  Within  the  selected  districts,  only  those  villages  will  be 
eligible for support that have (i) poverty levels higher than the district average, (ii) lower density 
of infrastructure than the district average, and (iii) not received support in the past 2 years for 
infrastructure development. Inclusion of the more specific criteria adds objectivity to the village 
selection,  and  the  use  of  additional  filters  helps  target  remote  and  isolated  villages  that  have 
been bypassed by previous projects/programs. The list of selected districts and villages will be 
finalized and submitted to the ADB prior to commencement of civil works and release of funds in 
each of the Project districts.

Poverty Targeting

6. 

Good Governance and Anticorruption Measures 

32. 
Implementation  of  infrastructure  works  through  a  community-led  approach  is  the 
underlying principle of the Project design. The Project clearly recognizes that administration at 
the village level is the most transparent and democratic in the country and that there are several 
self-governing checks and balances at the village level to militate against corruption. Given that 
the Project aims to alleviate poverty, the main thrust of the anticorruption agenda has been to 
ensure that the beneficiaries directly receive the funds with the minimum amount of delay and 
that there are no leakages at the village level. The communities will be involved at all stages of 
infrastructure  rehabilitation  and  improvement.  The  Project  incorporates  good  governance 
through features including (i) advance socialization of the overall program objectives so that the 
communities understand the intentions, the outcomes, and the process by which funds will be 
disbursed;  (ii)  a  detailed  and  consensual  approach  to  planning  so  that  the  village-level 
assessments  are  prepared  in  a  transparent,  consistent,  and  cost-effective  manner  with  clear 
awareness  in  the  communities  as  to  how  much  they  are  receiving  and  for  what;  (iii)  smooth, 
transparent,  fast,  and  direct  disbursement  and  funds  flow  to  the  village;  (iv)  transparent 
utilization of Project funds at the village level, so that the utilization is adequately controlled with 
regular and transparent record keeping; and (v) comprehensive monitoring and evaluation that 
allows for an independent assessment of the  village investment outputs compared to the plan 
and overall program objectives.

Implementation  through  such  a  transparent  approach  is  well  tested  and  proven  for 
promoting  good  governance.  Details  from  an  assessment  of  existing  financial  management

71. 
Experiences  on  past  rural  development  projects  show  tendencies  wherein  the  benefits

transparency  and  good  governance.  In  addition,  an  assessment  of  the  ongoing  PKPS-BBM 
undertaken by ADB staff suggests that the existing financial management systems and fiduciary 
controls are sound and have adequate checks and balances to minimize the corruption-related

outputs, and prevent fraud and corruption.

319  kwh/capita,  with  45%  of  households  not  connected  to  electricity  at  all.  Some  90  million

12. 
Agriculture in Indonesia is dominated by irrigated rice. About 82% of the rice produced in 
the country is grown under irrigation. Of the total irrigated area, 5.0 million hectares are publicly 
managed and 1.2 million hectares, all comprising small systems, are managed by farmers. The

rural  poverty.  As  a  result  of  these  investments,  rice  production  increased  at  an  annual  rate  of

substantially contributed to reducing the incidence of rural poverty from 40% in 1970 to 16.5% in

production and related activities.

below levels necessary to maintain the existing systems. Some 60–80% of the available budget 
is  absorbed  by  regional  staff  salaries,  while  the  remainder  goes  to  emergency  repairs  and

Villagers’  investment  decisions  are  taken  at  the  village  community  level.  Village  plans

BENEFITS ANALYSIS 
 

1. 
The Project will support rural infrastructure rehabilitation and improvement, providing about 
1,800 villages with financial resources and technical backstopping for small interventions, including 
village  roads,  bridges  and  culverts,  village  irrigation  schemes,  water  supply  and  sanitation.  As 
village  investments  will  follow  a  community-based  approach,  designs  and  costs  of  selected 
interventions will be determined during implementation. Quantifiable benefits will arise from village 
rural  investments  as  increased  rural  incomes  and  welfare,  but,  because  beneficiaries  determine 
investments,  the  Project’s  actual  inputs  and  outputs  cannot  be  predicted  up  front.  The  Project, 
therefore, does not lend itself to a traditional economic analysis. 
 
B. 

Likely Benefits and Impacts of Rural Infrastructure 

2. 
Rural  Infrastructure  Benefits. The more common benefits expected to accrue include (i) 
time  savings  in  collecting  water  and  cost  savings  in  obtaining  water;  (ii)  emergence  of  new 
businesses due to access to a water supply; (iii) time and cost savings due to faster transportation, 
including  more  efficient  transportation  of  goods  to  market;  (iv)  increase  in  the  value  of  land 
adjacent  to a  new  road;  (v)  new  employment  in  the  transport  sector;  (vi)  increase  in  the  value of 
agricultural land serviced by new irrigation works; (vii) increase in incomes due to better harvests 
resulting from reliable water supply; (viii) savings from potential damage to buildings and crops due 
to reduced flooding and improved irrigation, and (ix) creation of new businesses (roads). 
 
3. 
Employment  Generation.  The  Government  of  Indonesia’s  Fuel  Subsidy  Reduction 
Compensation Program (PKPS-BBM) currently under implementation estimates that 30% to 50%

grant  utilization,  the  Project  is  anticipated  to  generate  an  average  of  100  person/months  of 
employment per village, or about a total 180,000 person/months. With an average labor wage of $3 
per  day,  the  short-term  employment  income  generated  by  the  Project  is  anticipated  to  be  about 
$14 million.

PKPS-BBM are anticipated to be similar in size and nature. 
 
12.

Bank,  an  independent  post-construction  analysis  of  113  rural  infrastructure  subprojects  funded 
under the KDP confirmed significant economic benefits accruing to villages that planned and built 
infrastructure  facilities  following  a  community-based  approach. 41  The  average  cost  net  of 
community contribution for these subprojects was about $12,000. Given that under the KDP each 
village  typically  received  support  for  two  infrastructure  subprojects,  the  average  support  for  each 
village amounted to $24,000, which is similar to the grant size under the proposed Project. In this
